newsitem.title: USA: FOCUS- K-III moves to pare debt, refocus.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS- K-III moves to pare debt, refocus.

text.p: K-III Communications Corp, in a move to pare debt and refocus its business, said Tuesday it would shed non-core operations and offer an additional 12.5 million shares of its common stock in a public sale.

The New York-based owner of the Channel One educational channel and specialty consumer magazines like Seventeen and Soap Opera Digest, could fetch anywhere from $250 million to $350 million from the sale of its non-core assets, analysts said. It could raise another $150 million through an offering of its stock, which fell 1/2 to 12-1/8 late Tuesday.
K-III will use the proceeds to reduce its roughly $2 billion in debt and outstanding preferred stock, measures analysts said would surely boost the company's current BB- and BA3 credit ratings.

Aiming for a growth rate of at least twice U.S. Gross Domestic Product growth, K-III said it would target six main areas: workplace learning; classroom learning; specialty consumer magazines; technical and trade magazines; consumer directories and business directories.
It said it would sell businesses it considers non-core, in markets which fell below its targeted growth rate.

Businesses slated for sale include the Daily Racing Form (with Pro-Football Weekly), Newbridge Book Clubs, New Woman Magazine and Krames Communications, as well as the Katherine Gibbs School, whose sale K-III announced last October.
The company derived about $260 million of its $1.37 billion in revenues from those businesses, or about $24 million in cash flow.
Analysts said the moves will make K-III a more tightly focused company after the sales and could help it concentrate on growing through small acquisitions to its six newly defined core areas.

"It's some of the best news we've seen come out of K-III in a long time," said Jacob Barker, who follows K-III's bonds for NationsBank. "You'll see a significant inprovement in their credit risk after this."

In a conference call with analysts after Tuesday's announcement, K-III said it expects to achieve a 15 percent overall annual growth rate going forward as a result of the moves, and that half of that growth would come internally, without acquisitions.

Analysts said the company was likely to achieve those estimates. They said that for shareholders, those growth prospects outweight any negative in the company potentially diluting its share price with a higher float, or more common shares outstanding.

K-III had about 134 million common shares outstanding as of January 30, when it announced its 1996 fourth-quarter and year-end results. After the 12.5 million share offering, slated for April, the company will have just under 150 million shares.
